title: Python basics
text:
Basic Operations and Expressions:
Python supports various operations like arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /), comparison operators (==, !=, <, >), logical operators (and, or, not), etc. Expressions combine variables, values, and operators to perform a specific computation.

title: Python basics
text:
Control Flow:
Control flow structures such as if statements, for loops, and while loops allow you to control the execution of your code based on certain conditions. Understanding how to use these structures enables you to write code that performs different actions under different circumstances.

title: Python basics
text:
Functions:
Functions are blocks of reusable code that perform a specific task. They help in organizing code and making it more modular. Understanding how to define, call, and pass arguments to functions is essential.

title: Python basics
text:
Data Structures:
Python provides built-in data structures like lists, tuples, dictionaries, and sets. Understanding these data structures and their properties is crucial for efficient data manipulation. Knowledge of when and how to use each data structure based on the requirements of your program is important.

title: Python basics
text:
Error Handling

Error handling is one of the most important concepts to understand and manage well. You will be spending 25-50% of your time debugging.
Debugging is the practice of looking for bugs (errors in the code) and trying to fix them.
When an error happens in python, an exception is raised. You then use the traceback to try and find the cause of the error.

title: Python basics
text:
File Handling:
Python provides various functions for reading from and writing to files. Understanding file handling operations is essential for working with external data. Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) (Optional for beginners but important for intermediate level):

title: Coding environment
text:
What are computers?

At its core, a computer is essentially a device that answers yes-no questions.
It answers these simple questions very very quickly.
By asking the computer millions of these yes-no questions, it can calculate answers to very complex questions.

title: Coding environment
text:
How do computers think?

Confused by the last statement? Let me expand…
Computers have lots of components to enable them to work.

Screen to show you its output.
Keyboard and mouse to allow you to communicate with the computer.
Inside the computer’s chassis:

Hard drives
Memory sticks
Fans
Power supplies
Motherboards
Processors


The processor of a computer is where all of the thinking takes place.

title: Coding environment
text:
Variables and Data Types:

A single variable is a space in the computer’s memory Variables are used to store data in a program. Understanding data types such as integers, floats, strings, booleans, lists, tuples, dictionaries, and sets is crucial. Variables allow you to manipulate and operate on data within your program.

NO SPACES

title: Coding environment
text:
How do computers think?

The processor is where these yes-no questions are undertaken.
The processor receives instructions in binary form.
Binary is basically a string of 1s and 0s (eg 01001011).
As modern computers communicate in binary (yes-no) form, they are said to be digital.
The processor reads these binary instructions.
Each instruction results in either a True or False answer (aka yes-no answer). The output (aka answer) is also in binary.

title: Coding environment
section: So how do we communicate with computers?
text:
So how do we communicate with computers?

So computers listen, think and talk in binary.
We need a method to communicate with them, to get them to do what we want them to do.
This is where programming languages come into play.

title: Coding environment
text:
Programming languages

There are over 9000 programming languages, but much less than this in routine use.
A programming language is written in somewhat of a human readable form (depends on the langauge).
Popular langauges include:

Javascript / typescript
C++
Go
Java
Swift
R
Python

title: Coding environment
text: How does a computer

title: Coding environment
text:
Translation

When you have written your code in your favourite programming language, a software program (called the interpreter or compiler) reads your code and translates it into 1s and 0s which the computer can then read and act upon.

title: Coding environment
text:
What is in a code?

You need different elements in your code to be able to tell the computer what to do. These include:

Variables
Operators
Expressions
Flow control
Functions
Error handling
More advanced functionalities

title: Coding environment
text:
Variables

A single variable is a space in the computer’s memory.
Simple inbuilt variables include:



variables_simple.py

a_string = "I am a string"
an_integer = 11
a_float = 8.04
a_boolean = True

title: Coding environment
text:
Variables

More complex variables include:



variables_more_complex.py

a_list = ["first element of list", "second element of list"]
another_list = [1,5,3,6]
a_dictionary = {
    "1st key": "1st value",
    "2nd key": "2nd value",
}
a_tuple = (1,2,3,4,6,7)
a_set = {4,2,5,3}

title: Coding environment
text:
Spaces

Variables names cannot have spaces, if you add a space, the computer will read this as two separate variables:



spaces.py

variable_a = "I am a variable"
variable b = "The added space will cause an error"

Syntax error:
    Cell In[1], line 2
        variable b = "The added space will cause an error"
                 ^
    SyntaxError: invalid syntax

title: Coding environment
text:
Basic Operators

Operators manipulate and compare data (which are stored in variables). Operator types include:

Arithmetic: + - * /
Comparison: == > <
Logical: and or not
Assignment: = += -= *=

title: Coding environment
text:
More Advanced Operators

These include:

Bitwise: & | ^ << >>
Membership: in   not in
Identity: is   is not

title: Coding environment
text:
Control Flow - if statements


if_statement.py

sky = "dark"

if sky == "blue":
    time_of_day = "day time"
elif sky == "grey"
    time_of_day = "dusk or dawn"
else:
    time_of_day = "night time"

print("Time of day is: ", time_of_day)

Output
    Time of day is: night time

title: Coding environment
text:
Control Flow - for loops


for_loop.py

list_of_numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

for number in list_of_numbers:
    print(number)

Output
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5

title: Coding environment
text:
Control Flow - while loops


while_loop.py

count = 1

while count <= 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1

Output
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5

title: Coding environment
text:
Naming conventions

There are several naming conventions for programming languages. In python, conventions are:

Variables, functions and methods

snake_case

Contants

CONSTANT_CASE

Classes (a higher organisation method in python)

CamelCase

Modules (a file with python code inside)

snake_case

Packages (a collection of modules)

lowercasepackagenames

title: Coding environment
text:
Functions (methods)

Blocks of reusable code that perform a specific task.
Help in organizing code and making it more modular.
Part of the DRY (do not repeat yourself) philosophy.
A method is just a function, used within a class (a higher organisation method in python)

title: Coding environment
text:
Functions (methods)


functions.py

def name_of_function(argument_1, argument_2):
    a_variable = argument_1 + argument_2
    another_variable = "a return value"

    print (a_variable)

    return another_variable

title: Coding environment
text:
Other code organisation

There are several other organisation practices in python, but we will leave these for another day.
Just so you are aware, these are:

classes
modules
packages

There are also some fancy syntax practices, but I will leave those for now.

title: Coding environment
section: Other things to be aware of
text:
Other things to be aware of

There are several other organisational practices in python, but we will leave these for another day.
Just so you are aware, these are:

classes
modules
packages

There are also some fancy syntax practices,
Reading inputs from the terminal,
File handling,
Object oriented programming.

title: Coding environment
text:
Error Handling

You can catch errors directly in your code, if you know an error might happen at a set location



functions.py

try:
    variable = 1 + "a"
except:
    print("I knew that you could not add an integer and a string!")
else:
    print("Somehow I did not get an error!")

Output
    I knew that you could not add an integer and a string!

title: Coding environment
text:
The Traceback

At first, this looks like a very complicated output
  Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 28, in <module>
          print(fruit_prices.get_price("pear"))
      File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 21, in get_price
          return self._price(fruit)
      File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 24, in _price
          return self.prices[fruit]
  KeyError: 'pear'

title: Coding environment
text:
The Traceback

When reading a Traceback, alwas read from the last line up.
  Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 28, in <module>
          print(fruit_prices.get_price("pear"))
      File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 21, in get_price
          return self._price(fruit)
      File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 24, in _price
          return self.prices[fruit]
  ==> KeyError: 'pear' <==

section: Compare the Traceback to the error_in_code

section: Compare the Traceback to the code

title: Coding environment
text:
Double or single quotation marks?

You will see people using ‘single’ and also “double” quotation marks. It does not matter which you chose, but be consistent. If you accidently mix pairs of quotation marks you will get strange errors



quotation_marks.py

variable_a = "All good here with two single qoutation marks"
variable_b = "I have the wrong matching qoutation marks'
variable_c = 'Single qoutation marks'


Suddenly variable_c is part of the string for variable_b

title: Coding environment
section: Using both types of Quotation marks
text:
Using both types of Quotation marks

You can embed qoutation marks within each other



quotation_marks.py

variable_a = "I want to highlight 'this' word"
variable_b = 'I would like to show you "this"'

title: Coding environment
text:
You got all that?

Now it is your turn
Time for some hands on coding lessions

title: Coding environment
text:
Indentation

Python is extremely sensitive to indentation. One extra space or tab in front of a line of code (an expression) and you will not hear the end of it in terms of errors or strange results. You use a tab for a line of code to show the computer which previous statement it relates to.

title: Coding environment
text:
Computers are pedantic!

Remember that computers think in True and False, 1 and 0s. They are literal thinkers. Even one character being out of place can break an entire code base. So watch out for that unpaired quotation mark, look out for that space that should not be there, make sure you match your indentiations to your if statements.
Now go have some fun in your groups with hands-on coding and debugging.

title: Coding environment
text:
Indentation


indentation.py

if door_locked == True:
    if key_in_door == True:
        turn_key()
        door_locker = False
        print("Door has been unlocked")
    else:
        print("Door locked and cannot be opened")
else:
    print("Door already unlocked")

print("Done")

Output (if door locked and key in door)
    "Door has been unlocked"
    "done"

title: Coding environment
text:
Indentation


indentation.py

if door_locked == True:
    if key_in_door == True:
        turn_key()
        door_locker = False
        print("Door has been unlocked")
    else:
        print("Door locked and cannot be opened")
else:
    print("Door already unlocked")

    print("Done")

Output (if door locked and key in door)
    "Door has been unlocked"

Using the terminal

Also called the command line interface (CLI).

Steps:

Select the terminal (aka click on it).
Type in your command (this needs to be typed out exactly).
Press enter to run the command.

Pro tip:

If you want to run a previously run command, you can select it with the ↑ and ↓ arrow keys on the keyboard.

title: Coding environment (and the shell)
text:
Lession 1

Join your tutor group in the Zoom break out rooms.
Follow the link to the online learning environment (Codespace).
Change the directory (don’t type the $. This is just how we show this is the command line):

    $ cd /workspaces/learn-python/{your_name}/module-1/hands-on

Replace {your_name} with your own name in the format firstname underscore lastname, eg john_doe.
Run the following command in the new directory

    $ python3 lession_1.py

Any problems, just ask your tutor for help.
There is no such thing as a stupid question, only the question left unanswered.
We will give you 20 minutes for lession 1.

Commands

A command is a piece of code that carries out a specific task.
These tasks can be as simple as showing you what folder you are in to printing, changing settings, and updating the operating system.

title: Introduction to module 1 - python and the shell
text:
Why learn to code?

We learn biology and anatomy at university to understand and practice clinical medicine, why not the base subject to understand and practice digital medicine?
Of course not all clinicians should be expected to have extensive knowledge in coding and digital health; that would take clinicians away from the front line, and also clinicians are expensive coders.
However, having a small number of subject matter experts in both disciplines can be highly advantageous to implementing better and safer digital health projects.

text:
Indentation

Python is extremely sensitive to indentation. One extra space or tab in front of a line of code (an expression) and you will not hear the end of it in terms of errors or strange results. Indentation (in the form of tabs) of expressions shows the computer which previous expression it relates to.

title: Python basics
text:
Computers are pedantic!

Remember that computers think in True and False, e.g. 1 and 0s. They are literal thinkers.
Even one character being out of place can break an entire code base. So watch out for that unpaired quotation mark, look out for that space that should not be there, and make sure you match your indentiations to your if statements.
Now go have some fun in your tutor groups with hands-on coding and debugging.

Comments are useful in explaining what code is supposed to do.

# This is a single line comment

''' Single quotation mark multiline comment
    Here is some more of the comment

def i_am_another_function():
    return True

def i_am_function(args1, args2):

    A description of the function.

        args1: I am the first argument to the function.
        args2: I am the second argument to the function.
    Returns:
        x: the addition of the 2 provided arguments.
    """

    x = args1 + args2
    
    return x

title: Module 1 - Where is the on switch?
text:
Why learn to code?

We learn biology and anatomy at university to better understand and practice clinical medicine. Why don’t we learn the base subject to better understand and practice digital medicine?
Of course not all clinicians should be expected to have extensive knowledge in coding and digital health; that would take clinicians away from the front line, and also clinicians are expensive coders.
However, having a small number of subject matter experts in both disciplines can be highly advantageous to implementing better and safer digital health projects.

Data analytics

Automate routine tasks
Help lead a software development team with knowledge of both digital and clinical aspects.
Indeed, anything digital

title: Python basics
text:
What are computers?

At its core, a computer is essentially a device that answers yes-no questions.
It answers these simple questions very very quickly.
By asking the computer millions of these yes-no questions, it can calculate answers to very complex questions.

title: Python basics
text:
How do computers think?

Confused by the last statement? Let me expand…
Computers have lots of components to enable them to work.

Screen to show you its output.
Keyboard and mouse to allow you to communicate with the computer.
Inside the computer’s chassis:

Hard drives
Memory sticks
Fans
Power supplies
Motherboards
Processors


The processor of a computer is where all of the thinking takes place.

title: Python basics
text:
How do computers think?

The processor is where these yes-no questions are undertaken.
The processor receives instructions in binary form.
Binary is basically a string of 1s and 0s (eg 01001011).
As modern computers communicate in binary (yes-no) form, they are said to be digital.
The processor reads these binary instructions.
Each instruction results in either a True or False answer (aka yes-no answer). The output (aka answer) is also in binary.

title: Python basics
section: So how do we communicate with computers?
text:
So how do we communicate with computers?

So computers listen, think and talk in binary.
We need a method to communicate with them, enabling us to get them to do what we want them to do.
This is where programming languages come into play.

title: Python basics
text:
Programming languages

There are over 9000 programming languages, but much less than this in routine use.
A programming language is written in somewhat of a human readable form (depends on the langauge).
Popular langauges include:

Javascript / typescript
C++
Go
Java
Swift
R
Python

title: Python basics
text:
Translation

When you have written your code in your favourite programming language, a software program (called the interpreter or compiler) reads your code and translates it into 1s and 0s which the computer can then read and act upon.

title: Python basics
text:
What is in a code?

You need different elements in your code to be able to tell the computer what to do. These include:

Variables
Operators
Expressions
Flow control
Functions
Error handling
More advanced functionalities

title: Python basics
text:
Variables

A single variable is a contained space in the computer’s memory.
Simple in-built variables include:



variables_simple.py

a_string = "I am a string"
an_integer = 11
a_float = 8.04
a_boolean = True

title: Python basics

More complex variables include:

    "1st key": "1st value",
    "2nd key": "2nd value",
}
a_tuple = (1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7)
a_set = {4, 2, 5, 3}

Error handling is one of the most important concepts to understand and manage well. You will be spending 25-50% of your time debugging.
Debugging is the practice of looking for bugs (errors in the code) and trying to fix them.
When an error happens in python, an exception is raised. You then use the traceback to try and find the cause of the error.

title: Python basics
text:
Python programming language

Python is a scripting language interpreted and compiled at runtime.
Its syntax emphasizes readability and simplicity, utilizing indentation for code structuring.
Python supports various programming paradigms, including procedural, object-oriented, and functional.
With a vast standard library and active community support, Python is widely used for web development, data analysis, AI, and automation.

title: Python basics
text:
The Python programming language

Python is a scripting language interpreted and compiled at runtime.
Its syntax emphasises readability and simplicity, utilising indentation for code structuring.
Python supports various programming paradigms, including procedural, object-oriented, and functional.
With a vast standard library and active community support, Python is widely used for web development, data analysis, AI, and automation.

title: Coding environment (and the shell)

In the context of this course, a development environment should be synonymous with the teaching environment.

title: Coding environment (and the shell)
text:
We will be using the GitHub Codespace development environment.
This is a browser version of the well known desktop VS Code development environment.
In the context of this course, a development environment should be synonymous with the teaching environment.

title: Coding environment (and the shell)
text:
Commands

A command is a piece of code that carries out a specific task.
These tasks can be as simple as showing you what folder you are in to printing, changing settings, and updating the operating system.

title: Coding environment (and the shell)
text:
Using the terminal

Also called the command line interface (CLI) or the shell.

Steps:

Select the terminal (aka click on it).
Type in your command (this needs to be typed out exactly).
Press enter to run the command.

Pro tip:

If you want to run a previously run command, you can select it with the ↑ and ↓ arrow keys on the keyboard.

title: Coding environment (and the shell)
text:
List files and folders command

The ls command.

title: Coding environment (and the shell)
text:
Change directory command

The cd command.
cd .. takes you back to the previous (parent) folder.

title: Coding environment (and the shell)
text:
Where am I?

pwd is the print working directory command.

title: Coding environment (and the shell)
text:
LiveShare

We will be using liveshare for the hands-on learning sessions. This is an extension of Codespace (and VS Code) that allows others to work (and learn) in the same development environment.

title: Coding environment (and the shell)
text: Codespace view

title: Coding environment (and the shell)
text:
Lession 1

Join your tutor group in the Zoom break out rooms.
Follow the link to the online learning environment (Codespace).
Change the directory (don’t type the $. This is just how we show this is the command line):

    $ cd users/{your_name}/modules/module-1/hands-on

Replace {your_name} with your own name in the format firstname underscore lastname, eg john_doe.
Run the following command in the new directory

    $ python3 lession_1.py

Any problems, just ask your tutor for help.
There is no such thing as a stupid question, only the question left unanswered.
We will give you 20 minutes for lession 1.

title: Clinicians-who-code course - module 1 - Where is the on switch?
text:
Why learn to code?

We learn biology and anatomy at university to better understand and practice clinical medicine. Why don’t we learn the base subject to better understand and practice digital medicine?
Of course not all clinicians should be expected to have extensive knowledge in coding and digital health; that would take clinicians away from the front line, and also clinicians are expensive coders.
However, having a small number of subject matter experts in both disciplines can be highly advantageous to implementing better and safer digital health projects.

title: Python basics
text:
At its core, a computer is essentially a device that answers yes-no questions.
It answers these simple questions very very quickly.
By asking the computer millions of these yes-no questions, it can calculate answers to very complex questions.

title: Python basics
text:
At its core, a computer is essentially a device that answers yes-no questions.
It answers these simple questions very very quickly.
By asking the computer millions of these yes-no questions, it can calculate answers to very complex questions.

title: Python basics
text:
How do computers think?

Confused by the last statement? Let me expand…
Computers have lots of components to enable them to work.

Screen to show you its output.
Keyboard and mouse to allow you to communicate with the computer.
Inside the computer’s chassis:

Hard drives
Memory sticks
Fans
Power supplies
Motherboards
Processors


The processor of a computer is where all of the thinking takes place.

title: Python basics
text:
How do computers think?

The processor is where these yes-no questions are undertaken.
The processor receives instructions in binary form.
Binary is basically a string of 1s and 0s (eg 01001011).
As modern computers communicate in binary (yes-no) form, they are said to be digital.
The processor reads these binary instructions.
Each instruction results in either a True or False answer (aka yes-no answer). The output (aka answer) is also in binary.

title: Python basics
section: So how do we communicate with computers?
text:
So how do we communicate with computers?

So computers listen, think and talk in binary.
We need a method to communicate with them, to get them to do what we want them to do.
This is where programming languages come into play.

title: Python basics
text:
Programming languages

There are over 9000 programming languages, but much less than this in routine use.
A programming language is written in somewhat of a human readable form (depends on the langauge).
Popular langauges include:

Javascript / typescript
C++
Go
Java
Swift
R
Python

title: Python basics
text:
Translation

When you have written your code in your favourite programming language, a software program (called the interpreter or compiler) reads your code and translates it into 1s and 0s which the computer can then read and act upon.

title: Python basics
text:
What is in a code?

You need different elements in your code to be able to tell the computer what to do. These include:

Variables
Operators
Expressions
Flow control
Functions
Error handling
More advanced functionalities

title: Python basics
text:
Variables

A single variable is a set space in the computer’s memory.
Simple in-built variables include:



variables_simple.py

a_string = "I am a string"
an_integer = 11
a_float = 8.04
a_boolean = True

title: Python basics
text:
Variables

More complex variables include:



variables_more_complex.py

a_list = ["first element of list", "second element of list"]
another_list = [1, 5, 3, 6]
a_dictionary = {
    "1st key": "1st value",
    "2nd key": "2nd value",
}
a_tuple = (1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7)
a_set = {4, 2, 5, 3}

title: Python basics
text:
Spaces

Variables names cannot have spaces, if you add a space, the computer will read this as two separate variables:



spaces.py

variable_a = "I am a variable"
variable b = "The added space will cause an error"

Syntax error:
    Cell In[1], line 2
        variable b = "The added space will cause an error"
                 ^
    SyntaxError: invalid syntax

title: Python basics
text:
Double or single quotation marks?

You will see people using ‘single’ and also “double” quotation marks. It does not matter which you chose, but be consistent. If you accidently mix pairs of quotation marks you will get strange errors



quotation_marks.py

variable_a = "All good here with two single qoutation marks"
variable_b = "I have the wrong matching qoutation marks'
variable_c = 'Single qoutation marks'


Suddenly variable_c is part of the string for variable_b

title: Python basics
section: Using both types of Quotation marks
text:
Using both types of Quotation marks

You can embed quotation marks within each other



quotation_marks.py

variable_a = "I want to highlight 'this' word"
variable_b = 'I would like to show you "this"'

title: Python basics
text:
f-strings

Userful to know



f_string.py

age = 25
print(f"The patient's age is : { age }")

title: Python basics
text:
Indentation

Python is extremely sensitive to indentation. One extra space or tab in front of a line of code (an expression) and you will not hear the end of it in terms of errors or strange results. Indentation (in the form of tabs) of expressions shows the computer which previous expression it relates to.

title: Python basics
text:
Indentation


indentation.py

if drug_prescribed == True:
    if drug_given == True:
        record_drug_given = True
        print("Drug has been prescribed and given to the patient")
    else:
        print("Drug has been prescribed but not given")
else:
    print("Drug has not been prescribed")

print("Drug round complete!")

Output (if drug has been prescribed and given)
    Drug has been prescribed and given to the patient
    Drug round complete!

title: Python basics
Python basics
text:
Naming conventions

There are several naming conventions for programming languages. In python, conventions are:

Variables, functions and methods

snake_case

Contants

CONSTANT_CASE

Classes (a higher organisation method in python)

CamelCase

Modules (a file with python code inside)

snake_case

Packages (a collection of modules)

lowercasepackagenames

title: Python basics
text:
Comments

Comments are useful in explaining what code is supposed to do.
They are essential for when you, and others, need to read your code later to problem solve or add to your code.
Use them sparingly, as they can clutter code.
Try and make variable and function names self explanatory.
You can comment with the hastag or encapsulate with triple quotation marks:



comments.py

# This is a single line comment
a_string = "a string"

""" Double quotation mark multiline comment
    Here is some more of the comment
"""
def i_am_a_function():
    return True

''' Single quotation mark multiline comment
    Here is some more of the comment
'''
def i_am_another_function():
    return True

title: Python basics
text:
Comments

You will also come across something called docstrings. These are basically comments associated with functions / methods and classes.
You will see them associated with modules (at the top of files).



docstrings.py

def i_am_function(args1, args2):
    """A concise title

    A description of the function.

    Args:
        args1: I am the first argument to the function.
        args2: I am the second argument to the function.
    Returns:
        x: the addition of the 2 provided arguments.
    """

    x = args1 + args2
    
    return x

title: Python basics
text:
Basic Operators

Operators manipulate and compare data (which are stored in variables). Operator types include:

Arithmetic: + - * /
Comparison: == > <
Logical: and or not
Assignment: = += -= *=

title: Python basics
text:
More Advanced Operators

These include:

Bitwise: & | ^ << >>
Membership: in   not in
Identity: is   is not

title: Python basics
text:
Control flow - if statements


if_statement.py

patient_allergy = "amoxicillin"

if patient_allergy == "amoxicillin":
    allergy_group = "penicillins"
elif patient_allergy == "tazocin":
    allergy_group = "penicillins"
else:
    allergy_group = "others"

print("Patient is allergic to", allergy_group)

Output
    Patient is allergic to penicillins

title: Python basics
text:
Control flow - for loops


for_loop.py

list_of_numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

for number in list_of_numbers:
    print(number)

Output
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5

title: Python basics
text:
Control flow - while loops


while_loop.py

count = 1

while count <= 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1

Output
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5

title: Python basics
text:
Functions (methods)

Blocks of reusable code that perform a specific task.
Help in organizing code and making it more modular.
Part of the DRY (don't repeat yourself) philosophy.
A method is just a function, used within a class (a higher organisation method in python).

title: Python basics
text:
Functions (methods)


functions.py

def name_of_function(argument_1, argument_2):
    a_variable = argument_1 + argument_2
    another_variable = "a return value"

    print (a_variable)

    return another_variable

title: Python basics
section: Other things to be aware of
text:
Other things to be aware of

There are several other organisational practices in python, but we will leave these for another day.
Just so you are aware, these are:

classes
modules
packages

There are also some fancy syntax practices,
Reading inputs from the terminal,
File handling, and
Object oriented programming.

title: Python basics
text:
Error Handling

Error handling is one of the most important concepts to understand and manage well. You will be spending 25-50% of your time debugging.
Debugging is the practice of looking for bugs (errors in the code) and trying to fix them.
When an error happens in python, an exception is raised. You then use the traceback to try and find the cause of the error.

title: Python basics
text:
Error Handling

If you know an error might happen at a set location, you can catch errors directly in your code:



functions.py

try:
    variable = 1 + "a"
except:
    print("I knew that you could not add an integer and a string!")
else:
    print("Somehow I did not get an error!")

Output
    I knew that you could not add an integer and a string!

title: Python basics
text:
The Traceback

At first, this looks like a very complicated output


    Traceback (most recent call last):
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 28, in <module>
            print(fruit_prices.get_price("pear"))
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 21, in get_price
            return self._price(fruit)
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 24, in _price
            return self.prices[fruit]
    KeyError: 'pear'

title: Python basics
text:
The Traceback

When reading a Traceback, alwas read from the last line up.


    Traceback (most recent call last):
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 28, in <module>
            print(fruit_prices.get_price("pear"))
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 21, in get_price
            return self._price(fruit)
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 24, in _price
            return self.prices[fruit]
    ==> KeyError: 'pear' <==

title: Python basics
section: Compare the Traceback to the code

title: Python basics
text:
You got all that?

Now it is your turn.
Time for some hands on coding in Lesson 2.

title: Python basics
text:
Computers are pedantic!

Remember that computers think in True and False, e.g. 1 and 0s. They are literal thinkers.
Even one character being out of place can break an entire code base. So watch out for that unpaired quotation mark, look out for that space that should not be there, and make sure you match your indentations to your if statements.
Now go have some fun in your tutor groups with hands-on coding and debugging.

Using both types of Quotation marks

You can embed quotation marks within each other



quotation_marks.py

variable_a = "I want to highlight 'this' word"
variable_b = 'I would like to show you "this"'

title: Python basics
text:
f-strings

Userful to know



f_string.py

age = 25
print(f"The patient's age is : { age }")

title: Python basics
text:
Indentation

Python is extremely sensitive to indentation. One extra space or tab in front of a line of code (an expression) and you will not hear the end of it in terms of errors or strange results. Indentation (in the form of tabs) of expressions shows the computer which previous expression it relates to.

title: Python basics
text:
Indentation


indentation.py

if drug_prescribed == True:
    if drug_given == True:
        record_drug_given = True
        print("Drug has been prescribed and given to the patient")
    else:
        print("Drug has been prescribed but not given")
else:
    print("Drug has not been prescribed")

print("Drug round complete!")

Output (if drug has been prescribed and given)
    Drug has been prescribed and given to the patient
    Drug round complete!

title: Python basics
Python basics
text:
Naming conventions

There are several naming conventions for programming languages. In python, conventions are:

Variables, functions and methods

snake_case

Contants

CONSTANT_CASE

Classes (a higher organisation method in python)

CamelCase

Modules (a file with python code inside)

snake_case

Packages (a collection of modules)

lowercasepackagenames

title: Python basics
text:
Comments

Comments are useful in explaining what code is supposed to do.
They are essential for when you, and others, need to read your code later to problem solve or add to your code.
Use them sparingly, as they can clutter code.
Try and make variable and function names self explanatory.
You can comment with the hastag or encapsulate with triple quotation marks:



comments.py

# This is a single line comment
a_string = "a string"

""" Double quotation mark multiline comment
    Here is some more of the comment
"""
def i_am_a_function():
    return True

''' Single quotation mark multiline comment
    Here is some more of the comment
'''
def i_am_another_function():
    return True

title: Python basics
text:
Comments

You will also come across something called docstrings. These are basically comments associated with functions / methods and classes.
You will see them associated with modules (at the top of files).



docstrings.py

def i_am_function(args1, args2):
    """A concise title

    A description of the function.

    Args:
        args1: I am the first argument to the function.
        args2: I am the second argument to the function.
    Returns:
        x: the addition of the 2 provided arguments.
    """

    x = args1 + args2
    
    return x

title: Python basics
text:
Basic Operators

Operators manipulate and compare data (which are stored in variables). Operator types include:

Arithmetic: + - * /
Comparison: == > <
Logical: and or not
Assignment: = += -= *=

title: Python basics
text:
More Advanced Operators

These include:

Bitwise: & | ^ << >>
Membership: in   not in
Identity: is   is not

title: Python basics
text:
Control flow - if statements


if_statement.py

patient_allergy = "amoxicillin"

if patient_allergy == "amoxicillin":
    allergy_group = "penicillins"
elif patient_allergy == "tazocin":
    allergy_group = "penicillins"
else:
    allergy_group = "others"

print("Patient is allergic to", allergy_group)

Output
    Patient is allergic to penicillins

title: Python basics
text:
Control flow - for loops


for_loop.py

list_of_numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

for number in list_of_numbers:
    print(number)

Output
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5

title: Python basics
text:
Control flow - while loops


while_loop.py

count = 1

while count <= 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1

Output
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5

title: Python basics
text:
Functions (methods)

Blocks of reusable code that perform a specific task.
Help in organizing code and making it more modular.
Part of the DRY (don't repeat yourself) philosophy.
A method is just a function, used within a class (a higher organisation method in python).

title: Python basics
text:
Functions (methods)


functions.py

def name_of_function(argument_1, argument_2):
    a_variable = argument_1 + argument_2
    another_variable = "a return value"

    print (a_variable)

    return another_variable

title: Python basics
section: Other things to be aware of
text:
Other things to be aware of

There are several other organisational practices in python, but we will leave these for another day.
Just so you are aware, these are:

classes
modules
packages

There are also some fancy syntax practices,
Reading inputs from the terminal,
File handling, and
Object oriented programming.

title: Python basics
text:
Error Handling

Error handling is one of the most important concepts to understand and manage well. You will be spending 25-50% of your time debugging.
Debugging is the practice of looking for bugs (errors in the code) and trying to fix them.
When an error happens in python, an exception is raised. You then use the traceback to try and find the cause of the error.

title: Python basics
text:
Error Handling

If you know an error might happen at a set location, you can catch errors directly in your code:



functions.py

try:
    variable = 1 + "a"
except:
    print("I knew that you could not add an integer and a string!")
else:
    print("Somehow I did not get an error!")

Output
    I knew that you could not add an integer and a string!

title: Python basics
text:
The Traceback

At first, this looks like a very complicated output


    Traceback (most recent call last):
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 28, in <module>
            print(fruit_prices.get_price("pear"))
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 21, in get_price
            return self._price(fruit)
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 24, in _price
            return self.prices[fruit]
    KeyError: 'pear'

title: Python basics
text:
The Traceback

When reading a Traceback, alwas read from the last line up.


    Traceback (most recent call last):
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 28, in <module>
            print(fruit_prices.get_price("pear"))
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 21, in get_price
            return self._price(fruit)
        File "/User/a_user/code/error_in_code.py", line 24, in _price
            return self.prices[fruit]
    ==> KeyError: 'pear' <==

title: Python basics
section: Compare the Traceback to the code

title: Python basics
text:
You got all that?

Now it is your turn.
Time for some hands on coding in Lesson 2.

title: Python basics
text:
Computers are pedantic!

Remember that computers think in True and False, e.g. 1 and 0s. They are literal thinkers.
Even one character being out of place can break an entire code base. So watch out for that unpaired quotation mark, look out for that space that should not be there, and make sure you match your indentations to your if statements.
Now go have some fun in your tutor groups with hands-on coding and debugging.

In the context of this course, a development environment is synonymous with the teaching environment.

title: Python basics
text:
At its core, a computer is essentially a device that answers yes-no questions.
It answers these simple questions very very quickly.
By asking the computer millions of these yes-no questions, it can calculate answers to very complex questions.
